triples.statement: To avoid Qatar's extreme summer heat, the event was held in November and December, making it the first World Cup not held in May, June, or July.
Morocco became the first African nation to reach the semi-finals of a World Cup, where they lost 0–2 to France.
The tournament victory has been viewed by some commentators as a poetic capstone to Lionel Messi's career, fulfilling a criterion for him to be considered the greatest player of all time.
The FIFA World Cup is a professional football tournament organized by FIFA for national football teams.
The FIFA World Cup is held every four years, was first played in Uruguay in 1930, and has been contested by 32 teams since 1998.
The tournament format consisted of eight round-robin groups followed by a 16-team knockout round.
The defending champions were France, who beat Croatia 4–2 in the 2018 FIFA World Cup Final.
The tournament in Qatar was the first World Cup to be held in the Arab world.
The 2022 World Cup was played in November and December, unlike previous tournaments typically held in June and July, due to Qatar's intense summer heat and humidity.
To avoid playing group matches in the following year, major European competitions scheduled their group stage matches to be completed before the World Cup.
FIFA confirmed the match schedule on July 15, 2020.
The close proximity of the venues allowed organizers to optimize stadium allocation for spectators and kick-off times for television audiences.
The tournament introduced new rules allowing teams to make up to five substitutions in normal time and an additional one in extra time.
A concussion substitution did not count towards a team's quota of regular substitutions.
This was the first time a dedicated concussion substitute was used during a World Cup.
National associations were required to register their interest by February 2, 2009.
Once a UEFA nation was guaranteed to host the 2018 World Cup, UEFA members were ineligible to bid for the 2022 event.
On December 2, 2010, the 22-member FIFA Executive Committee met in Zürich, Switzerland, to vote on the hosts for both the 2018 and 2022 tournaments.
The decision to award the 2022 World Cup to Qatar, a country assessed as having "high operational risk," drew criticism from media commentators.
Many critics considered the decision part of the FIFA corruption scandals that resulted in the 2015 FIFA corruption case.
The voting patterns for the 2022 host selection were as follows.

With an estimated cost exceeding $220 billion, the 2022 FIFA World Cup is the most expensive to date, although Qatari officials dispute this figure, stating the true cost was $8 billion plus other infrastructure development expenses.
Qatar intended for the stadiums to reflect its history and culture, with designs meeting criteria for legacy, comfort, accessibility, and sustainability.
The stadiums were equipped with cooling systems designed to reduce internal temperatures by up to 20°C (36°F).
Marketing materials described the stadiums as zero waste, with plans for the upper tiers to be disassembled after the World Cup and donated to countries with less developed sports infrastructure.
All five of the initial stadium projects were designed by German architect Albert Speer & Partners.
Of the eight stadiums used, the Al Bayt and Al Wakrah stadiums were the only indoor venues.
According to an April 2013 Merrill Lynch report, Qatari organizers asked FIFA to approve fewer stadiums because of rising costs.
Bloomberg reported that Qatar wanted to reduce the number of venues from the originally planned twelve to eight or nine.
Qatar's Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy (SC) stated it expected eight stadiums, located in or near Doha, with Al Khor being the exception.
Stadium 974, the first planned temporary stadium in FIFA World Cup history, was meant to be dismantled after the tournament but, as of November 2024, it remains abandoned at its original site.
Lusail Stadium, Al Bayt Stadium, Ahmad bin Ali Stadium, Education City Stadium, Al Thumama Stadium, and Al Janoub Stadium are slated to be significantly modified to reduce their capacity by half.

A table lists the host cities, stadiums, and their respective capacities: Al Bayt Stadium (68,895), Lusail Stadium (88,966), Ahmad bin Ali Stadium (45,032), Education City Stadium (44,667), Khalifa International Stadium (45,857), Al Thumama Stadium (44,400), Stadium 974 (44,089), and Al Janoub Stadium (44,325).
The 2022 World Cup was the first since 1930 where players did not need to take flights for matches and could stay at the same training base throughout the tournament.
A table lists the designated hotel and training site for each national team participating in the tournament.
Qatar still participated in the Asian qualifying stage because the first two rounds also served as qualification for the 2023 AFC Asian Cup.
Because Qatar won their group to reach the final stage, Lebanon, the fifth-best second-place team, advanced instead.

Of the 32 nations qualified for the 2022 FIFA World Cup, 24 had also competed in the 2018 tournament, including reigning champions France, who qualified through European qualification rather than automatically.
Canada returned to the World Cup after a 36-year absence, with their only previous appearance in 1986.
Wales made their first appearance in 64 years, the longest gap for any team, with their only prior participation in 1958.
Ghana, ranked 61st, was the lowest-ranked team to qualify.

Italy, four-time winners and reigning European champions, failed to qualify for a second consecutive World Cup for the first time in their history after losing in the qualification play-off semi-finals.
Italy became the fourth team to fail to qualify for a World Cup after winning the previous UEFA European Championship, following Czechoslovakia in 1978, Denmark in 1994, and Greece in 2006.
Both American Samoa and Samoa withdrew before the OFC qualification draw due to travel restrictions following the pandemic.
Tonga withdrew from qualification after the 2022 Hunga Tonga–Hunga Ha'apai eruption and tsunami.
Due to COVID-19 outbreaks in their squads, Vanuatu and the Cook Islands also withdrew because of travel restrictions.
Russia, the previous World Cup hosts, were disqualified from competing due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Teams had to submit their 55-player roster to FIFA by 21 October.
The deadline for teams to name their final squads was 13 November.
The final draw for the 2022 FIFA World Cup was held at the Doha Exhibition and Convention Center in Doha, Qatar, on 1 April 2022 at 19:00 AST, before qualification was complete.
At the time of the draw, the winners of the two inter-confederation play-offs and the UEFA Path A play-off were not yet known.
The draw was attended by 2,000 guests and led by Carli Lloyd, Jermaine Jenas, and Samantha Johnson, with assistance from football figures including Cafu, Lothar Matthäus, Ali Daei, and Tim Cahill.
For the draw, 32 teams were placed into four pots based on the FIFA Men's World Rankings of 31 March 2022.

The draw pots were as follows: Pot 1 contained Qatar, Brazil, Belgium, France, Argentina, England, Spain, and Portugal. Pot 2 contained Mexico, Netherlands, Denmark, Germany, Uruguay, Switzerland, United States, and Croatia. Pot 3 contained Senegal, Iran, Japan, Morocco, Serbia, Poland, South Korea, and Tunisia. Pot 4 contained Cameroon, Canada, Ecuador, Saudi Arabia, Ghana, Wales, Costa Rica, and Australia.
For the first time, women referees officiated games at a major men's tournament.
Stéphanie Frappart of France, Salima Mukansanga of Rwanda, and Yoshimi Yamashita of Japan were the first female referees to be appointed to a men's World Cup.
On December 1, Stéphanie Frappart became the first woman to referee a World Cup match, officiating the Group E game between Costa Rica and Germany.
Juan Pablo Belatti was an assistant referee in the 2018 World Cup final.
Other returning officials included referees César Arturo Ramos of Mexico and Janny Sikazwe of Zambia, and Iranian assistant referee Mohammadreza Mansouri.
The ceremony featured appearances by Morgan Freeman and Ghanim Al-Muftah, as well as performances by Jungkook of BTS and Qatari singer Fahad Al Kubaisi.
This was the first time the Qur'an was recited during a World Cup opening ceremony.
Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani declared the tournament open during the ceremony.
The group stage was played from 20 November to 2 December.

The ranking of teams in the group stage was determined by a series of tie-breaking criteria: points, goal difference, goals scored, head-to-head results, fair play points, and finally, a drawing of lots.
Ecuador won 2-0 with two goals from Enner Valencia, after having a goal disallowed in the opening minutes.
Qatar became the first host nation to lose their opening match at a World Cup.
Many Qatar natives were seen leaving the opening match before it ended, with ESPN reporting that two-thirds of the attendees had left.
Cody Gakpo scored in the 84th minute and Davy Klaassen added a second goal in stoppage time.
This result made Qatar the first team eliminated from the tournament and the first host nation to be knocked out after only two games.
Cody Gakpo scored his second tournament goal to give the Netherlands a lead over Ecuador, but Enner Valencia scored an equalizer in the 49th minute.
The Netherlands defeated Qatar 2-0 with goals from Gakpo and Frenkie de Jong to win the group, while Qatar became the first host nation to lose all three of its group matches.
The victory was sufficient for Senegal to qualify as the runners-up of Group A.
Iran's goalkeeper, Alireza Beiranvand, was substituted due to a suspected concussion before England scored three goals in the first half.
After Mehdi Taremi scored in the second half, England's defender Harry Maguire was also substituted due to a concussion.
In the Iran vs. Wales match, substitute Rouzbeh Cheshmi scored in the eighth minute of stoppage time, and Ramin Rezaeian scored three minutes later.
The match between England and the United States ended in a 0–0 draw, featuring only four total shots on target and a shot by Christian Pulisic that hit the crossbar.
England secured the top spot in the group by defeating Wales 3–0, with one goal from Phil Foden and two from Marcus Rashford.
The United States defeated Iran 1–0 to qualify for the round of 16, with Christian Pulisic scoring the winning goal.
Saudi Arabia defeated Argentina 2-1 in what was considered a major upset, with goals from Saleh Al-Shehri and Salem Al-Dawsari overcoming an early penalty by Lionel Messi.
The match between Mexico and Poland ended in a 0-0 draw after Guillermo Ochoa saved a penalty from Robert Lewandowski.
Robert Lewandowski scored his first career World Cup goal in Poland's 2-0 victory over Saudi Arabia.
Argentina defeated Mexico 2-0, with Lionel Messi scoring the first goal and assisting Enzo Fernández for his first international goal.

Argentina won the group by defeating Poland with goals from Alexis Mac Allister and Julián Álvarez; Poland also advanced to the knockout stage on goal difference, aided by a late goal Saudi Arabia scored against Mexico.
The match between Denmark and Tunisia was a goalless draw, with both teams having goals disallowed for offside.
Danish midfielder Christian Eriksen made his first major international appearance since his cardiac arrest at UEFA Euro 2020.
France won 4–1 against Australia, with goals from Adrien Rabiot, Kylian Mbappé, and two from Olivier Giroud.
Olivier Giroud's two goals tied him with Thierry Henry as France's all-time top goalscorer.
Mathew Leckie's goal gave Australia a 1–0 victory over Denmark, allowing them to qualify for the knockout round as group runners-up.
Tunisia finished third in the group because they needed the Denmark vs. Australia match to be a draw.
Japan defeated Germany 2–1, with Ritsu Dōan and Takuma Asano scoring in the second half after an early penalty by Germany's İlkay Gündoğan.
Spain's goals against Costa Rica were scored by Dani Olmo, Marco Asensio, Ferran Torres (who scored twice), Gavi, Carlos Soler, and Alvaro Morata.
This 7-0 defeat was the largest in a World Cup since Portugal beat North Korea by the same score in 2010.
Costa Rica beat Japan 1–0, with Keysher Fuller scoring on Costa Rica's first shot on target in the tournament.
Germany and Spain played to a 1–1 draw, with goals from Álvaro Morata for Spain and Niclas Füllkrug for Germany.
Álvaro Morata scored the first goal for Spain against Japan, with Spain controlling the first half.
This marked the second consecutive World Cup where four-time champions Germany did not advance beyond the group stage.
Japan finished first in the group, ahead of Spain.
The first match in Group F between Morocco and Croatia ended in a goalless draw.
Second-half goals from Zakaria Aboukhlal and Romain Saïss secured Morocco's first World Cup match victory since 1998.
The match between Belgium and Morocco sparked riots in Belgium, involving fires and fireworks.
Croatia defeated Canada 4–1 with goals from Marko Livaja, Lovro Majer, and two from Andrej Kramarić.
Canada's goal in their match against Morocco was an own goal by Nayef Aguerd.
A goalless draw between Croatia and Belgium resulted in the elimination of Belgium, the world's second-ranked team, from the tournament.
Breel Embolo scored the only goal in Switzerland's 1–0 victory over Cameroon.
Richarlison scored two goals in Brazil's victory over Serbia, during which Neymar sustained an ankle injury.
Cameroon later scored goals via Vincent Aboubakar and Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting, resulting in a 3–3 draw with Serbia.
A goal by Casemiro in the 83rd minute secured Brazil's victory over Switzerland and their qualification for the knockout stage.
Vincent Aboubakar, who already had a yellow card, was sent off after receiving a second one for removing his shirt while celebrating his goal.
Despite their win, Cameroon did not qualify for the next stage because Switzerland beat Serbia 3–2.
Uruguay and South Korea's match ended in a 0-0 draw.
The match between Portugal and Ghana ended with a 3–2 victory for Portugal.
Mohammed Kudus scored again in the 68th minute, securing a 3–2 win for Ghana.
Portugal beat Uruguay 2–0 with two goals from Bruno Fernandes, which secured their advancement to the knockout stage.
Late in the game, a controversial penalty was awarded for a suspected handball by José María Giménez.
Goals from Kim Young-gwon and Hwang Hee-chan resulted in a 2–1 victory for South Korea.
Giorgian de Arrascaeta scored twice in Uruguay's 2–0 victory over Ghana.
Despite their win, Uruguay was eliminated, finishing third based on goals scored, because South Korea also won their match.
After the game, several Uruguayan players surrounded the referees and followed them off the pitch.
If the score was still tied after extra time, a penalty shoot-out was used to determine the winner.
The Netherlands defeated the United States 3–1, with goals from Memphis Depay, Daley Blind, and Denzel Dumfries for the Netherlands, and one from Haji Wright for the United States.
Argentina won 2–1 against Australia, with goals from Messi and Julián Álvarez, despite an own goal by Enzo Fernández.
After a 1–1 draw with goals from Daizen Maeda for Japan and Ivan Perišić for Croatia, Croatia defeated Japan 3–1 in a penalty shoot-out.
Brazil defeated South Korea 4–1, with goals from Vinícius Júnior, Neymar, Richarlison, and Lucas Paquetá for Brazil, and one from Paik Seung-ho for South Korea.
After a 0–0 draw, Morocco defeated Spain 3–0 on penalties.
Portugal defeated Switzerland 6–1, featuring a hat-trick by Gonçalo Ramos, additional goals from Pepe, Raphaël Guerreiro, and Rafael Leão, while Manuel Akanji scored for Switzerland.
Croatia won the penalty shootout against Brazil 4–2.
The match went to extra time and then penalties, with Argentina winning 4–3.
Morocco became the first African and Arab nation to advance to the semi-finals of the World Cup.
Argentina defeated Croatia 3–0, with a penalty from Messi and two goals from Julián Álvarez.
Randal Kolo Muani scored in the 78th minute, securing a 2–0 victory for France over Morocco and their place in a second consecutive final.
Mislav Oršić scored the winning goal for Croatia, resulting in a final score of 2–1.
Morocco's 4th place finish was a team record and the best World Cup result for any African or Arab nation.
Both Argentina and France had previously won the World Cup twice.
Early goals by Lionel Messi and Ángel Di María gave Argentina a 2–0 lead against France.
Mbappé scored the penalty and added a second goal less than two minutes later to equalize the score.
Mbappé scored his third goal, becoming the second player to complete a hat-trick in a World Cup final, after Geoff Hurst for England in 1966.
Argentina won the final 4–2 in the penalty shootout, scoring all of their penalties.
This was Argentina's third World Cup win, their first since 1986, and they became the second team (after Spain in 2010) to win the tournament after losing their opening game.
Two own goals were scored during the tournament.
This was the highest number of goals ever scored in a FIFA World Cup.
A player is automatically suspended for the next match for specific offences.
A table lists players who received suspensions during the tournament, detailing their offences and the matches they missed.
The award for the tournament's best goal was won by Brazil's Richarlison for his second goal in the group stage match against Serbia.
The official emblem, designed by Unlock Brands, was unveiled in September 2019 at simultaneous events in Doha Tower, Katara Cultural Village amphitheatre, Msheireb Downtown Doha, and Zubarah.
The emblem's wordmark typography incorporated kashida, an Arabic script practice of elongating characters for emphasis.

Qatar's Ambassador to the UN in Geneva, Dr. Hend Al-Muftah, stated that the tournament was an opportunity to promote Qatari culture and hospitality, and to demonstrate the country's commitment to sustainable development, social inclusion, and mutual respect.
The update for FIFA 23 added World Cup-themed tournament modes, two stadiums, Ultimate Team content, and real-time squad and fixture updates.
The 2022 Panini collection included rare cards with colored borders that could be collected, traded, or sold.
On April 12, 2022, FIFA launched an over-the-top media service and app called FIFA+, allowing fans to play games, predict matches, and compete.
The 2018 FIFA World Cup was watched by 3.57 billion people throughout the tournament.
Controversies surrounding the World Cup in Qatar led to questions about how the media would cover the tournament and whether these issues would be addressed.
The group stage match between England and the United States drew approximately 20 million viewers on Fox and Telemundo, ranking it among the highest-rated soccer broadcasts in the U.S.
According to FIFA's official website, Laʼeeb is known for his youthful spirit and has a backstory claiming he comes from a parallel world where tournament mascots live.
To promote the World Cup, two match balls were sent to and returned from space by FIFA and Qatar Airways on a SpaceX Falcon 9 suborbital mission.

The Al Hilm ball is technically identical to the Al Rihla but has a different color design (Gold Metallic, maroon, Collegiate Burgundy, and red) that references the national colors of Qatar, the final's venue, and the FIFA World Cup Trophy.
The first song of the album is "Hayya Hayya (Better Together)", performed by Trinidad Cardona, Davido, and AISHA, and was released on April 1, 2022.
The second song, "Arhbo", performed by Gims and Ozuna, was released on August 19, 2022.
The third song, "The World Is Yours to Take", was performed by American rapper Lil Baby and released on September 23, 2022.
The fourth song, "Light The Sky", was performed by Nora Fatehi, Manal, Rahma Riad, and Balqees, composed by RedOne, and released on October 7, 2022.
A fifth song, "Tukoh Taka", performed by Nicki Minaj, Maluma, and Myriam Fares, was released on November 17, 2022, and served as the official song of the FIFA Fan Festival.
The song "Dreamers" was performed with Fahad Al-Kubaisi during the tournament's opening ceremony.

Criticism of the 2022 FIFA World Cup centered on Qatar's human-rights record, including their treatment of migrant workers, women, and their position on LGBT rights, which led to allegations of sportswashing.
Other criticisms of Qatar hosting the World Cup included its climate, lack of a strong football culture, and allegations of bribery and wider FIFA corruption.
Several countries, clubs, and individual players declared boycotts of the event, and former FIFA president Sepp Blatter twice stated that awarding hosting rights to Qatar was a mistake.
The FIFA World Cup achieved record-breaking numbers of TV viewers in multiple markets.
A study by Arcom found that six out of ten French people watched at least one match.

Although a FIFA internal investigation cleared Qatar of any violation, chief investigator Michael J. Garcia stated that FIFA's report on his inquiry had "numerous materially incomplete and erroneous representations."
In May 2015, Swiss federal prosecutors initiated an investigation into corruption and money laundering concerning the 2018 and 2022 World Cup bids.
According to some investigations, Qatar hired former CIA officer Kevin Chalker to spy on rival bid teams and key football officials to gain an advantage in the 2010 selection process.

In September 2018, the al-Ghufran tribe filed a complaint with FIFA's president, asking that the World Cup not be held in Qatar until the government restored their nationality and returned land allegedly taken for sports facilities.
In September 2023, reports emerged that court documents revealed a $300 million transfer to individuals who voted on the 2022 World Cup host.

Qatar received significant criticism for its treatment of foreign workers, with Amnesty International citing "forced labour" and poor conditions, and many workers reporting they had to pay large recruitment fees.
Amnesty International, however, stated that the living and working conditions for foreign workers had not improved in recent years.
In response to Qatar's alcohol laws, World Cup organizers established designated "sobering-up" zones to avoid widespread arrests of intoxicated fans.
Nasser Al Khater, Qatar's World Cup chief executive, said the sobering-up areas were intended to ensure fan safety.
Fans sent to a "sobering up" zone were allowed to leave once they could demonstrate clearheaded behavior.
The controversy was characterized by multiple news agencies as a "cultural clash" between social conservatism and Islamic morality versus the norms of secular Western liberal democracies.
Several groups and media outlets raised concerns about Qatar's suitability as a host for the event.
In December 2020, Qatar announced that rainbow flags would be permitted at the 2022 FIFA World Cup.
Initially, Qatari officials said they would not ban the display of pride flags at venues but advised LGBT attendees to adhere to the country's modesty customs and avoid public displays of affection.
Hassan Abdulla al-Thawadi, the chief executive of Qatar's World Cup bid, stated that alcohol consumption would be allowed during the event, despite public drinking being prohibited.
Plans existed to permit the sale of alcohol within stadiums and at fan villages.

Due to climate conditions, some considered hosting the tournament in Qatar infeasible, leading to a date change from summer to November-December instead of relying on initial plans for air-conditioned stadiums.
In May 2014, Sepp Blatter, who was FIFA president during the selection, called the decision to award the World Cup to Qatar a "mistake" due to the extreme heat.
When speaking to delegates from African and Asian confederations, Blatter claimed that corruption allegations and other criticisms were heavily connected to racism and discrimination.
Match attendance figures were scrutinized because reported numbers exceeded stadium capacities, even though there were visibly empty seats at the games.
Before the tournament, a Danish TV reporter was threatened by security during a live broadcast, for which the organizing committee apologized, calling it a mistaken interruption.
Tony O'Donoghue of Ireland's RTÉ also accused Qatari police of interrupting him during filming.
This controversy contributes to the existing scrutiny of Qatar's successful bid to host the 2022 World Cup.
In November 2022, a lower court in Geneva ordered the publication to temporarily remove Rajat Khare's name and photo from the article.
As a result, he is currently referred to as an entrepreneur, although his name still appears in a Reuters article about his involvement in the hacking.
The hacking group was reportedly hired by Swiss-based private investigators Jonas Rey, who were in turn hired by Qatari officials.
In a survey of 1,000 workers, 86% reported that labor changes had improved their lives and that it was possible to negotiate better working conditions.
Changes to the Kafala system have resulted in labor mobility.

Sharan Burrow, general secretary of the International Trade Union Confederation, stated before the tournament that new laws would end the Kafala system and create a modern industrial relations system.
FIFA President Gianni Infantino has defended Qatar's hosting of the tournament.
The Economist has asserted that Qatar's human rights record is superior to that of Russia and China, and that the country faced excessive criticism for being chosen as the host.
Concerns were raised about holding the World Cup in Qatar during its traditional June and July timeframe due to the country's climate.
A task force was commissioned in October 2013 to consider alternative dates and was to report its findings after the 2014 FIFA World Cup in Brazil.

On February 24, 2015, the FIFA Task Force proposed playing the tournament from late November to late December 2022 to avoid summer heat and conflicts with the 2022 Winter Olympics, 2022 Winter Paralympics, and Ramadan.
FIFA executive committee member Theo Zwanziger said that awarding the event to Qatar was a "blatant mistake".
Frank Lowy, chairman of Football Federation Australia, said they would seek compensation from FIFA if a move to November disrupted the A-League's schedule.

Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, stated that the league would consider legal action against FIFA because a move would interfere with its popular Christmas and New Year fixture programme.
In 2015, FIFA confirmed the final would be played in December.
Critics condemned the allegations of disruption as Euro-centric and questioned why global sporting events must be held during the traditional European summer season.
A former employee of the Qatar bid team alleged that Qatar paid $1.5 million to several African officials.
The former employee retracted her claims but later stated she was coerced into doing so by Qatari bid officials.
In March 2014, it was discovered that former CONCACAF president Jack Warner and his family received a payment of almost $2 million from a firm associated with Qatar's successful bid campaign.
FIFA vice-president Jim Boyce stated he would support a re-vote to select a new host if the corruption allegations were proven.
Qatari officials insisted the corruption allegations were driven by envy and mistrust, while Sepp Blatter claimed they were fueled by racism in the British media.
The arrests were based on information about a corruption and bribery scandal amounting to at least $150 million.
Of those arrested, $40 million was forfeited through guilty pleas.
In 2022, Reynaldo Vasquez, the president of the El Salvador soccer association, was sentenced to 16 months in prison in connection with over $350,000 in bribes.
Following the corruption case, former Qatar bid team media officer Phaedra Almajid claimed the allegations would lead to Qatar not hosting the World Cup.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Audit and Compliance Committee, stated that the World Cup awards to Qatar and Russia could be cancelled if there was evidence they were secured only through bought votes.
Garcia investigated all nine bids and eleven countries involved in the 2018 and 2022 bidding processes.

The summary report cleared Qatar and Russia of bribery allegations, stating that while Qatar involved the Aspire Academy in its bid in significant ways, it did not compromise the integrity of the overall bid process.
Michael Garcia reacted almost immediately, stating that the summary report is "materially incomplete" and contains "erroneous representations of the facts and conclusions."
The full report did not provide evidence of corruption against the 2022 World Cup host but stated that bidders had tested the rules of conduct to their limit.

On December 9, 2019, the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) gave Russia a four-year ban from major sporting events after the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA) was found non-compliant for providing manipulated lab data.
While the ban was active, a team representing Russia and using its flag and anthem could not participate under the WADA decision.
Following an appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, on December 17, 2020, Russian teams were banned from competing in WADA-sanctioned world championships until December 16, 2022.
On February 24, 2022, the Czech Republic, Poland, and Sweden, the three teams in Russia's qualifying path, announced they were unwilling to play any matches in Russian territory.

Under these sanctions, Russia was not permitted to compete using its country's name, flag, or national anthem; instead, the team would compete under the abbreviation of the Russian Football Union ("RFU").
The following day, FIFA suspended Russia from international competitions "until further notice," which included its participation in the 2022 FIFA World Cup.
The selection of Qatar to host the 2022 FIFA World Cup was criticized due to the country's restrictive laws, with fan security and homophobic chants from certain nations being points of discussion.
While teams were willing to pay the typical fine for kit violations, FIFA reportedly informed them on match day that wearing the armbands would result in at least a yellow card.
Security officials at stadiums confiscated rainbow-colored clothing and flags.
American journalist Grant Wahl was briefly detained for wearing a t-shirt with a rainbow on it.
The journalists criticized the Qatar Supreme Committee for not providing defibrillators in the stadium when they were trying to help Wahl.
In response, FIFA stated that according to the ambulance service, a defibrillator was available when paramedics arrived on the scene.
An autopsy performed in New York City revealed that Grant Wahl died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm.
Discrimination against women in Qatar was also criticized.

Women in Qatar have few freedoms and must get permission from male guardians to marry, study abroad on government scholarships, work in many government jobs, travel abroad, receive certain reproductive health care, and act as a child's primary guardian, even if divorced.
The criminal case was dropped months after the woman was permitted to leave Qatar.
In November 2022, reports suggested the Iranian government was collaborating with Qatari officials to suppress anti-government protests at the World Cup, in light of the Mahsa Amini protests.
Leaked documents and audio clips suggested that Iranian government officials corresponded with Qatari authorities to manage potential protesters.

In November 2022, the Qatari government revoked the visas for journalists from Iran International, a London-based news channel critical of the Iranian regime, who were planning to cover the World Cup.

During the Iran vs. England match on November 21, 2022, stadium security forces reportedly attempted to block Iranian fans carrying items with slogans considered unsympathetic to Iran's Islamic government.
Blocked items included t-shirts and signs with "Woman, Life, Freedom," Iran's previous flags, or slogans containing the name of Mahsa Amini.
This crackdown persisted throughout all of Iran's matches at the World Cup.
Qatari police detained Danish TV presenter Rasmus Tantholdt for filming fans with "Woman, Life, Freedom" slogans, some of whom had previously been abused by pro-government supporters.

section_path: Treatment of Jewish and Israeli visitors

triples.statement: Shortly before the World Cup began, Qatar banned both cooked kosher food and public Jewish prayer services, claiming it could not secure the safety of Jews.
An estimated 10,000 religious Jews from Israel and around the world attended the World Cup in Qatar.

While Jewish organizations complained about being unable to find cooked kosher food, the Israeli government stated it was happy with Qatar's efforts to meet its requests, which included kosher food, direct flights from Israel, and temporary diplomatic representation.
Multiple Israeli reporters at the tournament reported being harassed by fans from Arab nations who were waving Palestinian flags and chanting anti-Israeli slogans.
Some Israelis reported being escorted out of restaurants when their nationality was revealed.
The Israeli government warned its citizens traveling to the tournament to hide their Israeli identity due to safety concerns.
Tourists complained that the air conditioners in the cabins were ineffective, facilities were in disrepair, and the overall sleeping experience was disappointing.
A shortage of suitable and affordable accommodation increased demand for daily shuttle flights from nearby areas like Dubai, which had sufficient hotel rooms.
